results.title: The Comic Strip 2: Mr Jolly Lives Next Door/Consuela
results.brief_description: Mr Jolly Lives Next Door - The inappropriately named hit man “Mr Jolly” (Peter Cook) rents an office space next door to the alcoholic incompetents Rik and Ade (Rik Mayall and Adrian Edmondson), proprietors of “Dreamytimer Escorts”, London’s seediest escort service. Through a catalogue of mistakes and misunderstandings the deranged Mr Lovebucket (Peter Richardson), purveyor of wines and spirits to most London off-licences, he finds he has paid Rik and Ade 3,000 pounds to “take out Nicholas Parsons”. Murderous implications arise behind Mr Lovebucket’s back. “Consuelo” - John (Adrian Edmondson) returns to his ancestral home, “Brownstokes” with a pretty new wife, Jessica (Jennifer Saunders).

results.title: The Comic Strip 1: Eddie Monsoon/Didn't You Kill My Brother
results.brief_description: Eddie Monsoon - written by Adrian Edmondson - star of “The Young Ones”, is a mock documentary about a South African TV host who’s a lush - and very violent. He’s a slightly quieter version of Vivian from the “Young Ones”, but set in the real world. The film includes excerpts from Monsoon’s under- standably few TV appearances, and interviews with his ex-wife (played by Jennifer Saunders of Saunders and French) and ex-manager (played by Peter Richardson). “Didn’t you kill my Brother” - written by Alexei Sayle, Pauline Melville and David Stafford. It tells the story of twin criminal brothers, Carl and Moss Sterling (both played by Sayle). After five years in prison, Carl emerges with 428 academic qualifications, a gentle manner and a Liverpool accent. He sets up a legitimate bicycle-making business at the local youth centre. Carl’s brother Sterling is meanwhile running a racket where the kids steal every bicycle in sight so that he can respray and resell them. Eventually the brothers clash, with fatal results. Rated: PG

results.title: The Comic Spirit (TEFC)
results.brief_description: A look at the different elements of comedy, performed and workshopped by the New Shakespeare Company from the Open Air Theatre in Regent’s Park. Shows sequences from modern comedy routines and relates these ideas of the comic genre to scenes from a number of Shakespearian comedies.

results.title: The Comeback
results.brief_description: Arnold Schwarzenegger, world champion bodybuilder, attempts a comeback after a lengthy retirement. The film reveals the motivated psychology of a winner in sport. The tension and excitement backstage at the Mr Olympia contest at the Sydney Opera House provides a compelling insight to a sport that is generally regarded as little more than a freak show. Also features Tom Platz and Frank Zane.

results.title: The Columbia River
results.brief_description: A survey of the Columbia River System, the world’s largest single source of hydroelectric power. Shows the multi-purpose dams, discusses US-Canadian agreements for further development, and explains the value of the waterway in irrigation, navigation and flood control.

results.title: The Colour of Pomegranates; Legend of the Suram Fortress
results.creator_credit: Armenfilm U S S R and Sergo Paradjanov
results.brief_description: The Colour of Pomegranates is a stream of religious poetic and local iconography of astonishing beauty, based on the work of Armenian poet Sayat Nova. “Legend of the Suram fortress” is set in Georgia and was Paradjanov’s first film after eleven years enforced confinement. It is based on a Georgian legend and continues the tension of Paradjanov’s earlier works concerning free will and predestination. Dedicated to Georgian warriors, it is a bold metaphor for Georgia’s independence from “Mother Russia”.

results.title: The Colour of life
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Guy Glover and J.V. Durden
results.brief_description: This film probes the perennial miracle of the growth of a seedling, the seasonal upsurge of life in a forest giant, and the mysterious alchemy of a single leaf. Presented in magnified dimension through time-lapse photography and animated diagrams, a maple leaf and segments of a tree serve to illustrate the physiological processes that go on in all plants.

results.title: The Color of paradise = The Colour of paradise
results.creator_credit: Varahonar Film Company, Mehdi Karimi and Majid Majidi
results.brief_description: After the end of term at a school for the blind in Teheran, Mohammed, an eight year old blind boy, and his father make the long journey on foot and horseback back to their village in the northern highlands of Iran. Though Mohammed quickly settles back into his idyllic life in the country with his two sisters and his grandmother, his widower father, who wants to remarry, decides to send him to work for a blind carpenter far from home. The film starts with a child’s perception of the world and expands its vision to encompass the emotional complexities of the adult world. Dividing the focus evenly between Mohammed and his father, it provides insight into wider social and cultural issues at play which resonate deeply through the caustic comments of the boy’s grandmother. While the soundtrack’s constantly shifting chorus of birds, insects, wind and rain draws attention to the sounds Mohammad hears, the film also reveals the beauty he is unable to see. Moving through fields of flowers and misty forests, across streams and into the craggy backwoods country, it offers a visionary experience of the natural world. Cast includes Hossein Mahjoub, Mohsen Ramezani, Salime Feizi and Farahnaz Safari. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: The Color of man
results.creator_credit: University of California, Los Angeles and Robert Carl Cohen
results.brief_description: Explains the reason for variation in skin color of people of the different nationalities. The film describes how in prehistoric times humans living near the equator could not protect themselves from the direct ultra-violent rays of the sun, and did not survive unless they developed a protective pigment in their skin known as melanin. Similarly those living away from the direct ultra-violet developed a fair skin which permitted the rays to penetrate, for a certain amount of ultra-violet light is essential for life. Narrated by Robert Doubleday.

results.title: The Colonies and Britain
results.creator_credit: Crown Film Unit and Colonial Office
results.brief_description: Shows the part played by Britain in making her colonies, particularly those in Africa, technically and economically ready for self-government. Illustrates how the Colonial Office is taking measures in Africa to fight disease, plague and ignorance, how the valuable resources of the colonies are being surveyed and how the necessary technical equipment is being supplied to develop these resources for the benefit of the peoples of the area.
